Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Statistical Methodology and Theory for Mining High-Dimensional Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The area of high-dimensional modeling is developing rapidly. This research aims to push these developments forward to meet new challenges arising in different fields. In particular, the investigator studies (a). new statistical methodology and theory for mapping high-dimensional datasets onto a space with much-lower dimensions while assuring minimum distortion; (b). efficient and robust variable selection in semiparametic models; (c). a novel regularization approach to nonparametric model selection and estimation.


Modern computing power and scientific innovations allow scientists to easily collect high-dimensional data in various disciplines. Analysis of high-dimensional data poses many challenges and offers great opportunities to statisticians. The availability of high-dimensional data has reshaped statistical modeling. This proposal focuses on new statistical methodology and theory for knowledge discovery and information retrieval from high-dimensional data. The investigator plans to develop User-friendly computer programs for public use. The research will make significant contributions to areas outside statistics as well, including biology, computer science, biomedical engineering, medical informatics, economics, and so on. The integrated educational program includes substantial initiatives that will involve undergraduate and graduate students and expose them to state-of-the-art research in the topics related to the proposal. These include new courses, workshops and mentoring. The research results will be integrated into K-12 education and be applied to industrial research.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the explosive developments of information technology and biotechnology innovations, big data have become ubiquitous in many scientific fields such as biological science, medical science, public health, social sciences and finance, among others. We need new data analytic methods and theory in order to draw useful information and to make reliable discovery out of the massive amount of collected data. NSF Career award grant (DMS-08-46068) entitled “New Statistical Methodology and Theory for Mining High-Dimensional Data” provided financial support to the principal investigator and his research group from 09/01/2009 to 08/31/2015 to develop innovative techniques and theory for high-dimensional statistical modeling and inference.

The award funded 30 papers published in peer reviewed major statistical journals.  In those publications, we developed a host of powerful new statistical techniques for accomplishing important data analytic missions such as variable selection, feature screening, classification, correlation matrix estimation and graphical model inference. We also created software to implement the developed new methods in user-friendly packages that are distributed publicly at CRAN (the comprehensive R archive network).  Our research greatly advanced the statistical theory for understanding high-dimensional data. Some long-standing open problems were solved and some new research frontiers were explored. Our research generated impacts in other fields such as machine learning, optimization, econometrics and computational biology. By using our newly developed variable selection and classification methods, researchers can quickly analyze genomics data and identify which genes impact the development of cancer. Researchers can also use our newly developed graphical modeling methods to understand the complex interactions among genes, neurons and people in a social network.

This award helped fund four former PhD students and one current PhD student at University of Minnesota. Three former PhD students got tenure track assistant professor positions at Penn State University, Florida State University and McGill University in 2013 and 2015, respectively. One former PhD student works for Ancestry.com as a data scientist.

"This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.”


Last Modified: 09/05/2015
Modified by: Hui Zou
